journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Identification method for rotordynamic coefficients of cylindrical air bearing using an impact hammer

article-meta.aff: Institut Pprime, Université de Poitiers, France

author-notes.corresp: Mihai Arghir, Institut Pprime, Université de Poitiers, CNRS UPR 3346, SP2MI, Boulevard Marie et Pierre Curie, Téléport 2, BP 30179, 86962 Futuroscope Chasseneuil, France. Email: arghir@lms.univ-poitiers.fr

abstract.p: This study develops the use of an impact hammer as an excitation source for identifying the dynamic coefficients of cylindrical aerodynamic bearings. The test rig and the identification method were originally developed for being used with two electromagnetic shakers applying non-synchronous excitations. The test rig is of a floating bearing type which means that the bearing is (almost) freely vibrating around a fixed rotating shaft. The impact hammer can then easily replace the two shakers for providing a source of excitation. This design permits to study all kinds of gas bearings operating at rotation speeds up to 60 kr/min, the static load being applied directly on the bearing via a spring. The dynamic coefficients are identified by applying two distinct (linearly independent) impacts. A transfer function approach of the impedances enables to take into account the frequency dependence of the linear dynamic coefficients. Test results are presented for a bearing of diameter 30 mm, L/D = 1 and clearance 22 µm and compared with theoretical predictions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Aerodynamic bearings are a serious candidate for replacing traditional fluid film bearings or ball bearings in microturbines and high-precision rotating machines because they have low heat generation at high-speed operating conditions and do not require any lubrications or sealing system. Their main peculiarities are relatively low-load capacities and stiffness, negligible torque and low damping. In fact, they have a limited stability with regard to self-induced vibrations. Therefore, their design must be conducted with care and the theoretical prediction methods must be based on well-validated tools and experimental results. The experimental prediction of linearized dynamic coefficients of air bearings is not an easy task. High rotation speeds and very low clearances render the task particularly difficult. The complexity is increased by the fact that for gas-lubricated bearings, the dynamic coefficients depend on the excitation frequency.

Most of the experimental data published up to now concern the dynamic response of rotor supported by two identical air bearings. For example, in 1970, Cunningham et al.1 designed a vertical test rig for analysing the dynamic characteristics of aerostatic bearings. The rotor was axially supported by an aerostatic thrust bearing and guided by two identical bearings which were investigated. A Pelton-type air turbine machined into the rotor ensured rotation speeds up to 25 kr/min. The steady-state characteristics of the two externally pressurized air journal bearings were identified by modifying the static load applied at the centre of the shaft. This design showed a good reliability and was consequently used by other researchers for identifying the dynamic characteristics of different gas bearings. In 2004, Park and Kim2 used a test rig of the same design to study a new type of slot-restricted gas journal bearing. In 2006, the same design was also used by Belforte et al.3 to study the aerostatic gas bearings. San Andrès and coworkers tested different types of air bearings with the aid of a test rig consisting of a small rotor entrained by an electrical motor built into the shaft and attaining 100 kr/min. In 2003, Wilde and San Andres4 used this test rig to study hybrid gas bearings. These bearings had three lobes and three feeding orifices. In 2005, Zhu and San Andres5 studied the stability of Rayleigh step gas bearings. In 2006, hybrid flexure pivot-tilting pad gas bearings and simple hybrid bearing6,7 were also tested.

Static and dynamic characteristics of journal bearings are also intensively tested on test rigs, where they are ‘floating’ on the rotor. This design is widely used for incompressible fluid-lubricated bearings8,9 and was originally inspired by Glienicke.10 In 2008, Ertas et al.11,12 described a multi-purpose test rig for gas journal bearings. The test rig is able to measure the start-up torque and the frequency-dependent rotordynamic coefficients under high-temperature operating conditions. In 2009, Matta13 developed a simple floating bearing test rig for measuring the linear dynamic coefficients of cylindrical gas bearings by applying external excitations with two electromagnetic shakers. Complex impedances were approximated by first-order transfer functions for taking into account the frequency dependence of the linear dynamic coefficients. The experimental results were compared with theoretical predictions for estimating the reliability of the identification method.

This article is a continuation of the work previously published by Matta et al.14 The objective is to simplify the excitation process and minimize the acquisition procedure as well as the signal processing time effort. The external periodic excitations delivered by the shaker are replaced by a simple impact hammer which applies two independent forces. Experimental results in the frequency domain are then used to determine the complex impedances of the bearing. The method based on the use of the impact hammer was recently employed by San Andrés and Chirathadam15 for identifying the dynamic characteristics of a metal mesh foil bearing of diameter 28 mm. The authors reported identified dynamic coefficients for static loads of 3.5 N, rotation speeds up to 50 kr/min and excitation frequencies up to 200 Hz.

This study introduces the results obtained using the impact load excitations and the transfer function approach for a 30-mm diameter cylindrical air bearing with 22 µm radial clearance, statically loaded with 20 N and operating at 15 kr/min.

sec.title: Experimental set-up
sec.p:
The air bearing test facility depicted in Figure 1 was designed by Matta13 and detailed in a previous paper.14 The test rig consists of a spindle driving a rotor supported by a hydrostatic hybrid bearing. This bearing is located at the midlength of the rotor and the tested bearing is mounted at its non-drive end. Figure 1.
Test rig layout.

The floating bearing design is based on the assumption that the tested bearing is free to move in X and Y directions (Figure 2), while the shaft can only rotate around its axis. The hybrid bearings supporting the shaft must then have stiffness orders of magnitudes larger than that of the tested bearing; otherwise, its displacement will interfere with the vibration of the bearing housing. The shaft is therefore guided by two identical externally pressurized bearings of Lomakin type depicted in Figure 3. Four orifices inclined at 85° against shaft rotation inject water pressurized up to 75 bar into a circumferential groove located in the bearing midplane. Due to the high feeding pressure, each water-lubricated Lomakin hybrid bearing is characterized by high radial stiffness. In addition, the rotor has a large tilting stiffness because the two Lomakin bearings are largely spaced. The angled injection ensures a very low or negative cross-coupling stiffness, leading to a large effective damping. Hence, the test rig was operated up to 60 kr/min (the largest speed enabled by the spindle) without any sign of instability. The rotor is considered rigid because the first natural frequency of its freely supported mode is largely higher than the maximum attainable rotation speed. Figure 2.
Aerodynamic bearing system of coordinate impact direction. Figure 3.
Layout of the double Lomakin hybrid bearing with counter-rotating injection.

The tested bearing is made of graphite serrated in a stainless steel sleeve (Figure 4). Two conical parts are used for mounting the cylindrical sleeve in the housing. The static and the impact forces are applied on this housing that is freely floating on the rotor. In order to avoid the dynamic misalignment problem exhibited during previous tests,14 the housing is mounted on three flexible stingers fixed on a base plate. The stingers do not interfere with measurements because their stiffnesses are one order of magnitude lower than those of the tested bearing. The static load is vertically applied on the bearing by a manually driven bolt and nut system and spring. Its value is measured with a dynamometer. Figure 4.
Aerodynamic bearing mounted in the housing.

The impact hammer is attached to a platform fixed on the milling table and has a rotational degree of freedom around a pivot. This simple mounting enables to apply a repeatable 45° inclined impulse load (Figure 5). Impacts are hence delivered in two orthogonal directions that coincide with (X,Y) in Figure 2. The altitude of the hammer launching and its head (shape and material) will control the energy transferred by the impact. Figure 5.
The impact hammer mounting.

Inductance proximity probes are used for measuring the relative displacements between the rotor and the bearing. They are mounted on the right and left axial planes of the housing (two in each plane). The impacts are collinear with the proximity probes. The housing is also equipped with four accelerometers (two in each end plane). The hammer is provided with a dynamic force sensor mounted in its head. The rotation speed is measured by an electro-optic tachometer which also provides a phase reference value.
The rotordynamic characteristics of the bearing are identified for a fixed rotation velocity imposed by the spindle and a given static load measured by the dynamometer.

sec.title: Rotordynamic coefficients identification method
sec.p: The bearing floating on the rotor has two degrees of freedom; therefore, two linear independent impacts must be applied for identifying its dynamic characteristics. The equations of motion of the floating bearing following X input are (1)

The aerodynamic forces in the thin film are expressed using stiffness and damping dynamic coefficients. It is supposed that the impact force fx leads to small displacements x and y around the static equilibrium position. From the mathematical standpoint, these displacements must be an order of magnitude lower than the bearing radial clearance C, but for testing purposes, values as large as 20% C can be acceptable. The impulse load is measured by the dynamic force sensor mounted on the hammer head and the response of the bearing by the housing instrumentation (proximity probes and accelerometers). A similar equation of motion is written for the fy impact force.

The equation of motion (1) is transformed to the frequency domain (2) where the dynamic coefficients of the bearing are represented by impedance functions Zab=Kab+jωCab. After successively applying X and Y impacts, a linear system is obtained in the frequency domain (3)
The complex impedances are obtained by solving this linear system. The determinant of the left-hand matrix is (4)

The solution of the linear system (3) raises no problem because the determinant (4) is always non-zero for a loaded cylindrical bearing. A zero determinant can be obtained only for circular orbits obtained if the bearing has antisymmetric stiffness and damping matrices. This would be the case for hydrostatic or aerostatic bearings operating close to the centred position. A cylindrical aerodynamic bearing cannot operate unloaded and close to the centred position because it will be unstable. When loaded and eccentric, the stiffness and damping matrices of the cylindrical bearing will be of general form and the orbit described following the impact will be close to ellipses.

Ten impacts are applied in each direction and the results are ensemble-averaged for reducing the noise associated with measurements. The conventional dynamic coefficients (the vertical direction is associated to the static load) are obtained by solving the linear system (3) followed by a 45° rotation of impedances.

sec.title: Transfer function smoothing procedure
sec.p: The impedances calculated by solving equation (3) enable the identification of dynamic coefficients by simply using the definitions (5)

In fact, the impedances calculated from measured data are affected by noise and need a smoothing procedure. For bearings lubricated with incompressible fluids (oil or water), this procedure is quite simple because the dynamic coefficients do not vary with the excitation frequency.*
*Tilting pad journal bearings lubricated with oil or water are a notable exception. Due to the inertia of the pads, their dynamic coefficients may vary (at least theoretically) with the excitation frequency. It is then sufficient to separately plot the real and the imaginary parts of the impedance versus the excitation frequency and perform a polynomial least square fit of the results. The coefficients of the polynomial are the dynamic coefficients. For gas-lubricated bearings (or more generally when the lubricant is compressible), this identification procedure cannot be used because the linear dynamic coefficients vary with frequency of excitation: the stiffness of a compressible film increases with the excitation frequency, while the damping tends to zero. In this case, the compressible air film can be dynamically described as a viscoelastic material16,17 and the impedance (direct or cross-coupled) is modelled as a frequency-independent stiffness in parallel with a damped stiffness.

This approach is now used for identifying the stiffness and damping coefficients from measured impedances. The first-order transfer function for a viscoelastic model of the squeezed gas film yields (6) where s is the Laplace transform. The equivalence between the Fourier and the Laplace transforms for a sinusoidal perturbation (s = jω) enables to write the complex impedance as first-order transfer functions (7)

The complex impedance is estimated from measurements performed at different excitation frequencies, and the coefficients A0, A1 and B0 are then calculated using a nonlinear minimization method applied to the following function (8)
The coefficients A0, A1 and B0 thus calculated enable to obtain a smooth curve fit of the frequency-dependent stiffness and damping coefficients (9) (10)

sec.title: Measurement uncertainties
sec.p: The goal of the identification procedure is to find the ‘exact’ dynamic bearing coefficients from measured data. However, measurements are always inherently affected by errors due to instrumentation, data acquisition and environmental effects. The dynamic coefficients can be identified only under certain limits, with uncertainties.

The total error has two components: bias error and random error. By neglecting any imperfection in the device calibration and the data acquisition system, the elemental bias error may arise only from measurement drifts due to electronic or thermal problems. If performing only short-duration tests, measurement derivation could then be neglected. Generally, the typical test duration for identifying rotordynamic coefficients for a given static load and rotation speed is close to 20 min and bias errors are therefore neglected.

Random errors appear as a scatter of results when measurements are repeated for the same test conditions. They are due to limitations of the repeatability of the measurements (displacements, accelerations and forces), hardware configuration (A/D converter, processor, etc.) and operating conditions (sampling frequency and number of effective samples). Estimating these errors by rigorously considering all possible sources of errors might be very difficult if not impossible if taking into account that errors due to the Fourier transform must also be accounted for. A more rapid error analysis was then performed in a statistical sense by considering that the real and imaginary parts of the measured impedances follow a Gaussian distribution. This is true if all the measured data used in equation (3) follow a Gaussian distribution. This was verified for the records measured by the displacement and acceleration sensor. For example, Figure 6(a) depicts the histogram of the X1 displacement measurements compared to the Gaussian probability distribution. This is only an informative plot showing no irregular behaviour. The proof test is depicted in Figure 6(b) showing the plot of the cumulative distribution function of X1 measurements compared to the Gaussian cumulative distribution. Displacement measurements follow the regression line of the Gaussian distribution closely. Thus, random errors can be estimated using statistical analysis and are assumed to be proportional to the SD of 10 measurements of the impedances. Figure 6.
Histogram and cumulative distribution function plot.

The 95% confidence uncertainty assessment is employed (as indicated in references18,19). This means that 95 times out of 100 measurements, the true value of the real and imaginary parts of the impedance lies within ±u about the average value. This evaluation contains the effect of all error sources. It then follows that for each excitation frequency (i = 1, … , N), the dynamic coefficients identified using the simple definitions (5) are in a confidence interval given by the local uncertainty u (11) (12) where ui(K) and ui(C) represent the 95% uncertainties of stiffness and damping for the excitation frequency ωi, (σi)2 and (σi)2 are the variances of the real and imaginary parts of the impedance. Zi and n represents the number of tests (n = 10 in this study).

The precision of the identified coefficients is further enhanced by the use in a least square sense of transfer function approximation (7). The measurement uncertainties are thus reduced proportionally to the number N of different excitation frequencies ωi used in minimizing the function Φ(A0,A1,B0) given by equation (8).
The precision of the dynamic coefficients increases then as a function of N, and the global uncertainties of the stiffness and damping identified using equations (9) and (10) are (13)

sec.title: The experimental procedure
sec.p:
Impact hammers are widely used for modal analyses of mechanical structures. An impact force spectrum presents the advantage of a large bandwidth of excitation frequencies and so it may reduce the time needed for measurements. The bandwidth of an impact spectrum depends not only on the masses of the excited structure and the hammer head but also on the impact time. Figure 7 depicts the time domain representation of a typical impact applied to the tested housing in X and Y directions. For an impact force applied by a plastic head, the contact duration is about 0.6 ms, while it is reduced to 0.45 ms for a metallic head launched from the same altitude. The amplitude of the impulse load also increases about 25% and excites a different band of frequencies. Figure 8 shows a comparison between the spectra of impacts applied on the housing in X and Y directions for a plastic and a metallic head. For the first case, the spectrum reaches zero amplitude at 3000 Hz, while using a hard metallic head, this cut-off frequency is obtained at 4000 Hz. Consequently, the hardness of the hammer head controls the range of excited frequencies, and the metallic head shows the best performance because it excites a larger frequency range than the plastic one. In addition, a lower impact time leads to more accurate measurement, especially at high speeds. For these reasons, the metallic hammer head is used for all measurements. Figure 7.
Impact loads applied to the housing in X and Y directions by two hammer head materials. Figure 8.
Frequency representation of impact loads applied by two hammer head materials.

sec.title: Data acquisition
sec.p: The dynamic analysis requires the acquisition of all signals an instant before and following the impact and largely covering the damped response of the bearing housing. For this reason, the sampling frequency should be high enough to detect the impulse and satisfy the conditions of the Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem, but also moderate for avoiding excessive storage.

During the experiment, the signals are sampled simultaneously at 8192 samples/s over 1 s. This yields 8192 samples per channel and a frequency resolution of 1 Hz. The data acquisition startup is controlled by the force signal measured by the piezoelectric sensor mounted on the hammer. Once the dynamic analyser detects a force larger than 30 N, the data acquisition system displays all 10 channel signals (four displacements, four accelerations, one force and one rotating speed) and records them for processing.

sec.title: Signal processing
sec.p: All data were saved in the time domain. They were then injected into a signal processing procedure specially developed to transform the measured signals in the frequency domain, filter the runout from each channel and identify the bearing dynamic coefficients throughout the specified frequency range following equation (5).

As it was mentioned before, a large number of samples per channel (8192 samples/s) are used to record the impact and the damped response of the bearing. Data are acquired every second, and not all impacts are well located inside this time interval. The signal processing procedure needs only the significant samples, i.e. impacts located not too close to the end of the data acquisition interval. The processing procedure then uses only 2048 samples starting 1 ms before the impact moment and deletes the rest. This yields a record of only 0.25 s and a frequency resolution of 4 Hz. This choice was based on repeated tests that have shown that 2048 points are mainly sufficient to record the damped response of the bearing.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The geometric characteristics of the tested cylindrical journal bearing are D = L = 30 mm and C = 22 µm. The static load applied by a vertical spring is W = 20 N and the rotation speed 15,000 r/min. The bearing is only lightly loaded because the specific load is W/LD = 0.02 MPa.

The hammer excites a large bandwidth of frequencies but the fast Fourier transform (FFT) of the impact load shows that its spectrum decreases with increasing excitation frequencies. This result added to the fact that the stiffness of the aerodynamic bearing increases with the excitation frequency and leads to very small bearing displacements for high frequencies (Figure 9). Noise affects all the bandwidth and therefore the signal-to-noise ratio measured at large excitation frequencies is so low that this part of the spectrum can be hardly used for identifying dynamic coefficients. Figure 9.
Frequency representation of the bearing response following the impact excitation.

This difficulty could be solved by increasing the magnitude of the impact. However, high-impact loads would lead to large displacements in the lower part of the excited bandwidth and consequently invalidate the small perturbation assumption. The definition of the linear dynamic coefficients would be then hazardous. Special care is therefore taken in all measurements in order to ensure enough force for obtaining a significant (measurable) displacement of the bearing housing for a large enough bandwith but not excessive in order to avoid time domain displacements larger than 20% of the radial clearance.

In general, measurements showed that excitation frequencies up to 280 Hz present acceptable uncertainties due to a high signal-to-noise ratio. Figure 10 presents the signal-to-noise ratio of one of the accelerations versus the impact force.*
*The signal-to-noise ratio function hereby used is SNR = COH/(1 − COH). The coherence function COH(x, y) measures the linear dependence of one signal on another; its value is equal to the squared magnitude of the cross-spectrum of two signals divided by both power spectra, and ranges in value from 0 to 1. The signal-to-noise ratio has acceptable values for excitation frequencies comprised in the ranges 50–280 Hz and 450–650 Hz; otherwise, it is too low. However, only frequencies ranging from 50 to 280 Hz can be used for identifying the dynamic coefficients because (as shown in Figure 9) for larger values, the displacements become too small. Figure 10.
Signal-to-noise ratio (x acceleration versus impact force).

Figures 11 and 12 depict the identified stiffness and damping coefficients (direct and cross-coupled). Coefficients represented by symbols are the ensemble average of impedances stemming from 10 measurements and identified using equations (3) and (5). Continuous plots depict the results obtained by applying the first-order transfer function curve fit (7). Furthermore, these figures include bars representing local uncertainties given by equation (12) for each frequency. Figure 11.
Measured and approximated dynamic coefficients in x direction (Ω = 15 kr/min, W = 20 N). Figure 12.
Measured and approximated dynamic coefficients in y direction (Ω = 15 kr/min, W = 20 N).

Figure 13 shows the comparison between dynamic coefficients identified with the first-order transfer function curve fit and theoretical predictions. These latter set of results was obtained with a code developed in Le Lez.20 Coefficients are generally well estimated excepting the cross-coupled stiffness for low-excitation frequencies. Figure 13.
Comparison between numerical and identified coefficients (Ω = 15 kr/min, W = 20 N).

Compared to the measurements using sine wave excitations applied by two electromagnetic shakers,13,14 the method using an impact hammer is very efficient in terms of time effort for identifying the dynamic coefficients. Depending on the analysed bandwidth, the time needed for complete identification (delivering the excitation, data acquisition and signal treatment) is decreased by a factor of 10.

Nevertheless, the values of the uncertainties for the direct dynamic coefficients depicted in Figures 11 and 12 and estimated with equation (13) are comprised between 20% and 30%, being larger than those previously obtained using the periodic excitations (uncertainties reported in Matta13 and Matta et al.14 are less than 10%). This is due to the fact that the clearance of the tested bearing is small (22 µm) and the identification of linear dynamic coefficients is based on measurements of the ‘small’ displacements of the bearing around the static equilibrium position. On the other hand, the response to an impact is characterized by a high peak factor. Therefore, to avoid large displacements, the impact is light. However, light impacts cannot excite the bearing at high frequencies and consequently lead only to a limited frequency range, where the signal-to-noise ratio is acceptable. It is therefore almost impossible to respect the small perturbation constraint by applying an impact load without limiting the studied frequency range.

It was theoretically proven in Le Lez20 that uncertainties stemming from a finite perturbation method are proportional to dynamic displacements. This analysis was performed by comparing dynamic coefficients stemming from a first-order compressible Reynolds equation (therefore supposed to be exact) with results obtained by applying finite amplitude perturbations. The results showed that forces in a cylindrical air bearing oscillating around its equilibrium position with an amplitude equal to 20% of the radial clearance lead to dynamic coefficients that are affected by 20% relative error.

The high uncertainties could also be explained by the fact that gas-lubricated journal bearings are nonlinear (frequency-dependent) dynamic systems. However, the identification of force coefficients by an impulse load supposes that the tested dynamic system is mainly linear. Therefore, some questions can be raised by the use of the linear identification model for aerodynamic bearings. Nevertheless, the use of an impact hammer remains an effective method for identifying dynamic coefficients of bearings lubricated with incompressible fluids (oil or water). These bearings are known to have frequency-independent dynamic coefficients and larger clearances that enable higher impact forces.

sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: This study details the procedure for the identification of rotordynamic coefficients of a cylindrical aerodynamic bearing. The procedure can be used for any type of air bearing as long as its dynamic response is linear. The identification method is based on the measurements of the bearing responses to an impact force and the calculation of its dynamic impedances. The identification method is completed with a first-order transfer function curve fit that provides a continuous plot of dynamic coefficients versus excitation frequency. Compared to a previous measurement using sine wave excitations applied by two electromagnetic shakers, the main advantage of the present identification method is the reduction of the test duration. Depending on the analysed bandwidth, the time needed for complete identification can be decreased by an order of magnitude. The identified bearing coefficients show acceptable good agreement with theoretical predictions for frequencies up to 280 Hz. The main limitation of the identification method is the fact that large excitation frequencies cannot be conveniently excited with acceptable signal-to-noise ratios. The value of 280 Hz seems to be the upper limit of the use of the impact hammer for this class of aerodynamic bearings.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful to Région Poitou-Charentes for partially supporting this study.
